The **history of New Zealand** dates back at least 700 years to when it was
discovered and settled by [Polynesians](/wiki/Polynesia "Polynesia"), who
developed a distinct [Māori culture](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_culture "Māori culture")
centred on kinship links and land. The first European explorer to sight [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") was Dutch navigator [Abel
Tasman](/wiki/Abel_Tasman "Abel Tasman") on 13 December 1642.[1] The Dutch
were also the first non-natives to explore and chart New Zealand's coastline.
Captain [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James Cook"), who reached New Zealand
in October 1769 on the first of his three voyages,[2] was the first European
explorer to circumnavigate and map New Zealand. From the late 18th century,
the country was regularly visited by explorers and other sailors,
missionaries, traders and adventurers. In 1840 the [Treaty of
Waitangi](/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi "Treaty of Waitangi") was signed between
the British Crown and various Māori chiefs, bringing New Zealand into the
[British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") and giving Māori the
same rights as British subjects. There was extensive British settlement
throughout the rest of the century and into the early part of the next
century. War and the imposition of a European economic and legal system led to
most of New Zealand's land passing from Māori to
[Pākehā](/wiki/P%C4%81keh%C4%81 "Pākehā") (European) ownership, and most Māori
subsequently became impoverished.[3]

From the 1890s the [New Zealand Parliament](/wiki/New_Zealand_Parliament "New
Zealand Parliament") enacted a number of progressive initiatives, including
[women's suffrage](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_New_Zealand "Women's suffrage
in New Zealand") and [old age pensions](/wiki/Old_age_pensions "Old age
pensions"). The country remained an enthusiastic member of the British Empire,
and 110,000 men fought in [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") (see
[New Zealand Expeditionary Force](/wiki/New_Zealand_Expeditionary_Force "New
Zealand Expeditionary Force")). After the war New Zealand signed the [Treaty
of Versailles](/wiki/Treaty_of_Versailles "Treaty of Versailles") (1919),
joined the [League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"),
and pursued an independent foreign policy, while its defence was still
controlled by Britain.

When [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") broke out in 1939, New
Zealanders contributed to the defence of the British Empire; the country
contributed some 120,000 troops. From the 1930s the economy was highly
regulated and an extensive [welfare state](/wiki/Welfare_in_New_Zealand
"Welfare in New Zealand") was developed. Meanwhile, Māori culture underwent a
renaissance, and from the 1950s Māori began moving to the cities in large
numbers. This led to the development of a [Māori protest
movement](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_protest_movement "Māori protest movement") which in
turn led to greater recognition of the Treaty of Waitangi in the late 20th
century.

The country's economy suffered in the aftermath of the [1973 global energy
crisis](/wiki/1973_oil_crisis "1973 oil crisis"), the loss of New Zealand's
biggest export market upon Britain's entry to the [European Economic
Community](/wiki/European_Economic_Community "European Economic Community"),
and rampant inflation. In 1984, the [Fourth Labour
Government](/wiki/Fourth_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand "Fourth Labour
Government of New Zealand") was elected amid a [constitutional and economic
crisis](/wiki/1984_New_Zealand_constitutional_crisis "1984 New Zealand
constitutional crisis"). The interventionist policies of the [Third National
Government](/wiki/Third_National_Government_of_New_Zealand "Third National
Government of New Zealand") were replaced by "[Rogernomics](/wiki/Rogernomics
"Rogernomics")", a commitment to a [free market](/wiki/Free_market "Free
market") economy. Foreign policy after 1980 became more independent especially
in pushing for a [nuclear-free zone](/wiki/New_Zealand_nuclear-free_zone "New
Zealand nuclear-free zone"). Subsequent governments have generally maintained
these policies, although tempering the free market ethos somewhat.

## Māori arrival and
settlement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Māori arrival and settlement")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Polynesian_Migration.svg/300px-
Polynesian_Migration.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Polynesian_Migration.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Polynesian_Migration.svg "Enlarge")

Polynesian expansion (from [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") to the Polynesian
triangle.)

New Zealand was originally settled by [Polynesians](/wiki/Polynesians
"Polynesians") from [Eastern Polynesia](/wiki/Eastern_Polynesia "Eastern
Polynesia"). Genetic and archaeological evidence suggests that humans
emigrated from [Taiwan](/wiki/Taiwan "Taiwan") to [Melanesia](/wiki/Melanesia
"Melanesia") and then travelled east through to the [Society
Islands](/wiki/Society_Islands "Society Islands"); after a pause of 70 to 265
years, a new wave of exploration led to the discovery and settlement of New
Zealand.[4] The most current reliable evidence strongly indicates that initial
settlement of New Zealand occurred around 1280 CE.[4] Previous dating of some
[Kiore (Polynesian rat)](/wiki/Kiore "Kiore") bones at 50 – 150 CE has now
been shown to have been unreliable; new samples of bone (and now also of
unequivocally rat-gnawed woody seed cases) match the 1280 CE date of the
earliest archaeological sites and the beginning of sustained, anthropogenic
deforestation.[5]

The descendants of these settlers became known as the
[Māori](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_people "Māori people"), forming a distinct culture of
their own. The separate settlement of the tiny [Chatham
Islands](/wiki/Chatham_Islands "Chatham Islands") in the east of New Zealand
about 1500 CE produced the [Moriori](/wiki/Moriori "Moriori"); linguistic
evidence indicates that the Moriori were mainland Māori who ventured
eastward.[6]

The original settlers quickly exploited the abundant large game in New
Zealand, such as [moa](/wiki/Moa "Moa"), which were large
[flightless](/wiki/Flightless_bird "Flightless bird") [ratites](/wiki/Ratite
"Ratite") pushed to [extinction](/wiki/Extinction "Extinction") by about 1500.
As moa and other large game became scarce or extinct, Māori culture underwent
major change, with regional differences. In areas where it was possible to
grow [taro](/wiki/Taro "Taro") and [kūmara](/wiki/Sweet_potato "Sweet
potato"), horticulture became more important. This was not possible in the
south of the South Island, but wild plants such as fernroot were often
available and cabbage trees were harvested and cultivated for food. Warfare
also increased in importance, reflecting increased competition for land and
other resources. In this period, fortified [pā](/wiki/Pa_\(Maori\) "Pa
\(Maori\)") became more common, although there is debate about the actual
frequency of warfare. As elsewhere in the Pacific,
[cannibalism](/wiki/Cannibalism "Cannibalism") was part of warfare.[7]

[![Māori whānau from Rotorua in the
1880s](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Famille_Maori_1998-1361-139.jpg/220px-
Famille_Maori_1998-1361-139.jpg)](/wiki/File:Famille_Maori_1998-1361-139.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Famille_Maori_1998-1361-139.jpg "Enlarge")

Māori whānau from [Rotorua](/wiki/Rotorua "Rotorua") in the 1880s. Many
aspects of Western life and culture, including European clothing and
architecture, became incorporated into Māori society during the 19th century.

Leadership was based on a system of chieftainship, which was often but not
always hereditary, although chiefs (male or female) needed to demonstrate
leadership abilities to avoid being superseded by more dynamic individuals.
The most important units of pre-European Māori society were the
[whānau](/wiki/Wh%C4%81nau "Whānau") or extended family, and the
[hapū](/wiki/Hap%C5%AB "Hapū") or group of whānau. After these came the
[iwi](/wiki/Iwi "Iwi") or tribe, consisting of groups of hapū. Related hapū
would often trade goods and co-operate on major projects, but conflict between
hapū was also relatively common. Traditional Māori society preserved history
[orally](/wiki/Oral_history "Oral history") through narratives, songs, and
chants; skilled experts could recite the tribal genealogies
(_[whakapapa](/wiki/Whakapapa "Whakapapa")_) back for hundreds of years. Arts
included whaikōrero ([oratory](/wiki/Public_speaking "Public speaking")), song
composition in multiple genres, dance forms including [haka](/wiki/Haka
"Haka"), as well as weaving, highly developed wood carving, and [tā
moko](/wiki/T%C4%81_moko "Tā moko") (tattoo).

New Zealand has no native land mammals (apart from some rare bats) so birds,
fish and sea mammals were important sources of protein. Māori cultivated food
plants which they had brought with them from Polynesia, including [sweet
potatoes](/wiki/Sweet_potatoes "Sweet potatoes") (called kūmara),
[taro](/wiki/Taro "Taro"), [gourds](/wiki/Gourds "Gourds"), and
[yams](/wiki/Yam_\(vegetable\) "Yam \(vegetable\)"). They also cultivated the
[cabbage tree](/wiki/Cabbage_tree_\(Cordyline_australis\) "Cabbage tree
\(Cordyline australis\)"), a plant endemic to New Zealand, and exploited wild
foods such as fern root, which provided a starchy paste.

## Early contact
periods[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Early contact periods")]

### Early European
exploration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Early European exploration")]

[![Map depicts the western and northern coast of Australia \(labelled "Nova
Hollandia"\), Tasmania \("Van Diemen's Land"\) and part of New Zealand's North
Island \(labelled "Nova
Zeelandia"\).](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Thevenot_-
_Hollandia_Nova_detecta_1644.png/220px-Thevenot_-
_Hollandia_Nova_detecta_1644.png)](/wiki/File:Thevenot_-
_Hollandia_Nova_detecta_1644.png)

An early map of [Australasia](/wiki/Australasia "Australasia") during the
Golden Age of Dutch exploration and discovery (c. 1590s–1720s). Based on a
chart by [Joan Blaeu](/wiki/Joan_Blaeu "Joan Blaeu"), c. 1644.

[![=An engraving of a sketched coastline on white
background](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/Cook_chart_of_New_Zealand.jpg/220px-
Cook_chart_of_New_Zealand.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cook_chart_of_New_Zealand.jpg)

Map of the New Zealand coastline as Cook charted it on his [first
visit](/wiki/First_voyage_of_James_Cook "First voyage of James Cook") in
1769–70. The track of the _[Endeavour](/wiki/HMS_Endeavour "HMS Endeavour")_
is also shown.

The first Europeans known to reach New Zealand were the crew of Dutch explorer
[Abel Tasman](/wiki/Abel_Tasman "Abel Tasman") who arrived in his ships
_Heemskerck_ and _Zeehaen_. Tasman anchored at the northern end of the [South
Island](/wiki/South_Island "South Island") in [Golden Bay](/wiki/Golden_Bay
"Golden Bay") (he named it Murderers' Bay) in December 1642 and sailed
northward to [Tonga](/wiki/Tonga "Tonga") following an attack by local Māori.
Tasman sketched sections of the two main islands' west coasts. Tasman called
them _Staten Landt_ , after the _[States General of the
Netherlands](/wiki/States_General_of_the_Netherlands "States General of the
Netherlands")_ , and that name appeared on his first maps of the country. In
1645 Dutch cartographers changed the name to _Nova Zeelandia_ in Latin, from
_Nieuw Zeeland_ , after the [Dutch province](/wiki/Seventeen_Provinces
"Seventeen Provinces") of _[Zeeland](/wiki/Zeeland "Zeeland")_. It was
subsequently anglicised as _New Zealand_ by British naval captain [James
Cook](/wiki/James_Cook "James Cook") of [HM Bark
_Endeavour_](/wiki/HM_Bark_Endeavour "HM Bark Endeavour") who
[visited](/wiki/First_voyage_of_James_Cook "First voyage of James Cook") the
islands more than 100 years after Tasman during 1769–1770. Cook returned to
New Zealand on both of his subsequent voyages.

Various claims have been made that New Zealand was reached by other non-
Polynesian voyagers before Tasman, but these are not widely accepted. Peter
Trickett, for example, argues in _[Beyond Capricorn](/wiki/Beyond_Capricorn
"Beyond Capricorn")_ that the Portuguese explorer [Cristóvão de
Mendonça](/wiki/Crist%C3%B3v%C3%A3o_de_Mendon%C3%A7a "Cristóvão de Mendonça")
[reached New Zealand](/wiki/Theory_of_Portuguese_discovery_of_Australia
"Theory of Portuguese discovery of Australia") in the 1520s, and the [Tamil
bell](/wiki/Tamil_bell "Tamil bell")[8] discovered by
[missionary](/wiki/Missionary "Missionary") [William
Colenso](/wiki/William_Colenso "William Colenso") has given rise to a number
of theories,[9][10] but historians generally believe the bell 'is not in
itself proof of early Tamil contact with New Zealand'.[11][12][13]

From the 1790s, the waters around New Zealand were visited by British, French
and American [whaling](/wiki/History_of_whaling "History of whaling"),
[sealing](/wiki/Seal_hunting "Seal hunting") and trading ships. Their crews
traded European goods, including guns and metal tools, for Māori food, water,
wood, [flax](/wiki/New_Zealand_flax "New Zealand flax") and
[sex](/wiki/Prostitution "Prostitution").[14] Māori were reputed to be
enthusiastic and canny traders, even though the levels of technology,
institutions and property rights differed greatly from the standards in
European societies.[15] Although there were some conflicts, such as the
killing of French explorer [Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne](/wiki/Marc-
Joseph_Marion_du_Fresne "Marc-Joseph Marion du Fresne") in 1772 and the
[destruction of the _Boyd_](/wiki/Boyd_massacre "Boyd massacre") in 1809, most
contact between Māori and European was peaceful.

### European
settlement[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: European settlement")]

Further information: [Pākehā settlers](/wiki/P%C4%81keh%C4%81_settlers "Pākehā
settlers")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Mission_House_at_Kerikeri.jpg/220px-
Mission_House_at_Kerikeri.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mission_House_at_Kerikeri.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Mission_House_at_Kerikeri.jpg "Enlarge")

The [Mission House](/wiki/Mission_House "Mission House") at Kerikeri is New
Zealand's oldest surviving building, having been completed in 1822

European ([Pākehā](/wiki/P%C4%81keh%C4%81 "Pākehā")) settlement increased
through the early decades of the 19th century, with numerous trading stations
established, especially in the North Island.
[Christianity](/wiki/Christianity_in_New_Zealand "Christianity in New
Zealand") was introduced to New Zealand in 1814 by [Samuel
Marsden](/wiki/Samuel_Marsden "Samuel Marsden"), who travelled to the [Bay of
Islands](/wiki/Bay_of_Islands "Bay of Islands") where he founded a mission
station on behalf of the Church of England's [Church Missionary
Society](/wiki/Church_Missionary_Society "Church Missionary Society").[16] By
1840 over 20 stations had been established. From missionaries, the Māori
learnt not just about Christianity but also about European farming practices
and trades, and how to read and write.[17] Beginning in 1820, linguist [Samuel
Lee](/wiki/Samuel_Lee_\(linguist\) "Samuel Lee \(linguist\)") worked with
Māori chief [Hongi Hika](/wiki/Hongi_Hika "Hongi Hika") to transcribe the
[Māori language](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_language "Māori language") into written
form.[16]

The first full-blooded European infant in the territory, Thomas Holloway King,
was born on 21 Feb 1815 at the Oihi Mission Station near Hohi Bay[18] in the
Bay of Islands. [Kerikeri](/wiki/Kerikeri "Kerikeri"), founded in 1822, and
[Bluff](/wiki/Bluff,_New_Zealand "Bluff, New Zealand") founded in 1823, both
claim to be the oldest European settlements in New Zealand.[19] Many European
settlers bought land from Māori, but misunderstanding and different concepts
of land ownership led to conflict and bitterness.[17] In 1839, the [New
Zealand Company](/wiki/New_Zealand_Company "New Zealand Company") announced
plans to buy large tracts of land and establish colonies in New Zealand.[20]
This alarmed the missionaries, who called for British control of European
settlers in New Zealand.

### Māori
response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Māori response")]

The effect of contact on Māori varied. In some inland areas life went on more
or less unchanged, although a European metal tool such as a fish-hook or hand
axe might be acquired through trade with other tribes. At the other end of the
scale, tribes that frequently encountered Europeans, such as
[Ngāpuhi](/wiki/Ng%C4%81puhi "Ngāpuhi") in [Northland](/wiki/Northland_Region
"Northland Region"), underwent major changes.[16]

Pre-European Māori had no distance weapons except for
[tao](/wiki/Tao_\(spear\) "Tao \(spear\)") (spears)[21] and the introduction
of the [musket](/wiki/Musket "Musket") had an enormous impact on Māori
warfare. Tribes with muskets would attack tribes without them, killing or
enslaving many.[22] As a result, guns became very valuable and Māori would
trade huge quantities of goods for a single musket. From 1805 to 1843 the
[Musket Wars](/wiki/Musket_Wars "Musket Wars") raged until a new balance of
power was achieved after most tribes had acquired muskets. In 1835, the
peaceful [Moriori](/wiki/Moriori "Moriori") of the [Chatham
Islands](/wiki/Chatham_Islands "Chatham Islands") were attacked, enslaved, and
nearly exterminated by mainland [Ngāti Mutunga](/wiki/Ng%C4%81ti_Mutunga
"Ngāti Mutunga") and [Ngāti Tama](/wiki/Ng%C4%81ti_Tama "Ngāti Tama")
Māori.[23] In the 1901 census, only 35 Moriori were recorded although the
numbers subsequently increased.[24]

Around this time, many Māori converted to Christianity.[16] The reasons for
this have been hotly debated, and may include social and cultural disruption
caused by the Musket Wars and European contact. Other factors may have been
the appeal of a religion that promotes peace and forgiveness, a desire to
emulate the Europeans and to gain a similar abundance of material goods, and
the Māori's [polytheistic](/wiki/Polytheistic "Polytheistic") culture that
easily accepted the new God.

## British
sovereignty[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: British sovereignty")]

In 1788 the [Colony of New South Wales](/wiki/Colony_of_New_South_Wales
"Colony of New South Wales") had been founded. According to the future
Governor, Captain [Arthur Phillip](/wiki/Arthur_Phillip "Arthur Phillip")'s
amended Commission, dated 25 April 1787 the colony of New South Wales included
"all the islands adjacent in the Pacific Ocean within the latitudes of 10°37'S
and 43°39'S" which included most of New Zealand except for the southern half
of the South Island.[25] In 1825 with [Van Diemen's
Land](/wiki/Van_Diemen%27s_Land "Van Diemen's Land") becoming a separate
colony, the southern boundary of New South Wales was altered[26] to the
islands adjacent in the Pacific Ocean with a southern boundary of 39°12'S
which included only the northern half of the North Island. However, these
boundaries had no real impact as the New South Wales administration had little
interest in New Zealand.[27]

New Zealand was first mentioned in British statute in the [Murders Abroad Act
1817](/wiki/Murders_Abroad_Act_1817 "Murders Abroad Act 1817"). It made it
easier for a court to punish "murders or manslaughters committed in places not
within His Majesty's [dominions](/wiki/Dominion "Dominion")",[28] and the
[Governor of New South Wales](/wiki/Governor_of_New_South_Wales "Governor of
New South Wales") was given increased legal authority over New Zealand.[29]
The jurisdiction of the [Supreme Court of New South
Wales](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_New_South_Wales "Supreme Court of New South
Wales") over New Zealand was initiated in the [New South Wales Act
1823](/wiki/New_South_Wales_Act_1823 "New South Wales Act 1823"), and lesser
offences were included at that time.[30][31] In response to complaints from
missionaries, about lawless sailors and adventurers in New Zealand, the
[British government](/wiki/British_government "British government") appointed
[James Busby](/wiki/James_Busby "James Busby") as Official Resident in 1832.
In 1834 he encouraged Māori chiefs to assert their sovereignty with the
signing of the _[Declaration of
Independence](/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Independence_of_New_Zealand
"Declaration of the Independence of New Zealand")_ in 1835. This was
acknowledged by King [William IV](/wiki/William_IV_of_the_United_Kingdom
"William IV of the United Kingdom"). Busby was provided with neither legal
authority nor military support and was thus ineffective in controlling the
European population.

### Treaty of
Waitangi[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Treaty of Waitangi")]

Main article: [Treaty of Waitangi](/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi "Treaty of
Waitangi")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Treatyofwaitangi.jpg/220px-
Treatyofwaitangi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Treatyofwaitangi.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Treatyofwaitangi.jpg "Enlarge")

One of the few extant copies of the [Treaty of
Waitangi](/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi "Treaty of Waitangi")

In 1839, the [New Zealand Company](/wiki/New_Zealand_Company "New Zealand
Company") announced its plans to establish colonies in New Zealand. This and
the increased commercial interests of merchants in Sydney and London spurred
the British to take stronger action. Captain [William
Hobson](/wiki/William_Hobson "William Hobson") was sent to New Zealand to
persuade Māori to cede their [sovereignty](/wiki/Sovereignty "Sovereignty") to
the [British Crown](/wiki/British_Crown "British Crown"). In reaction to the
New Zealand Company's moves, on 15 June 1839 a new Letters patent was issued
to expand the territory of New South Wales to include all of New Zealand.
[Governor of New South Wales](/wiki/Governor_of_New_South_Wales "Governor of
New South Wales") [George Gipps](/wiki/George_Gipps "George Gipps") was
appointed Governor over New Zealand. This was the first clear expression of
British intent to annexe New Zealand.

On 6 February 1840, Hobson and about forty Māori chiefs signed the [Treaty of
Waitangi](/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi "Treaty of Waitangi") at
[Waitangi](/wiki/Waitangi,_Northland "Waitangi, Northland") in the [Bay of
Islands](/wiki/Bay_of_Islands "Bay of Islands"). Copies of the Treaty were
subsequently taken around the country to be signed by other chiefs. A
significant number refused to sign or were not asked but, in total, more than
five hundred Māori eventually signed.

The Treaty gave Māori sovereignty over their lands and possessions and all of
the rights of British citizens. What it gave the British in return depends on
the language-version of the Treaty that is referred to. The English version
can be said to give the British Crown sovereignty over New Zealand but in the
Māori version the Crown receives _kawanatanga_ , which, arguably, is a lesser
power (see [interpretations of the
Treaty](/wiki/Treaty_of_Waitangi#Meaning_and_interpretation "Treaty of
Waitangi")). Dispute over the true meaning and the intent of either party
remains an issue.

Britain was motivated by the desire to forestall other European powers (France
established a very small settlement at [Akaroa](/wiki/Akaroa "Akaroa") in the
[South Island](/wiki/South_Island "South Island") later in 1840), to
facilitate settlement by British subjects and, possibly, to end the
lawlessness of European (predominantly British and American) whalers, sealers
and traders. Officials and missionaries had their own positions and
reputations to protect.

Māori chiefs were motivated by a desire for protection from foreign powers,
the establishment of governorship over European settlers and traders in New
Zealand, and to allow for wider settlement that would increase trade and
prosperity for Māori.[32]

Hobson died in September 1842. [Robert FitzRoy](/wiki/Robert_FitzRoy "Robert
FitzRoy"), the new governor, took some legal steps to recognise Māori
custom.[33] However, his successor, [George Grey](/wiki/George_Grey "George
Grey"), promoted rapid [cultural assimilation](/wiki/Cultural_assimilation
"Cultural assimilation") and reduction of the land ownership, influence and
rights of the Māori. The practical effect of the Treaty was, in the beginning,
only gradually felt, especially in predominantly Māori regions.

### The colonisation
project[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: The colonisation project")]

At first New Zealand was administered from Australia as part of the colony of
New South Wales. On 1 July 1841 New Zealand [became a colony in its own
right](/wiki/Colony_of_New_Zealand "Colony of New Zealand").[33]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Edward_Gibbon_Wakefield_bust.jpg/170px-
Edward_Gibbon_Wakefield_bust.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edward_Gibbon_Wakefield_bust.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edward_Gibbon_Wakefield_bust.jpg "Enlarge")

A bust of Edward Wakefield from the 1897 book _New Zealand rulers and
statesmen from 1840 to 1897_

British writer [Edward Gibbon Wakefield](/wiki/Edward_Gibbon_Wakefield "Edward
Gibbon Wakefield") (1796–1862) exerted a far-reaching influence. His plans for
systematic British colonisation focused on a free labour system, in contrast
to the slavery in the United States and the convict labour in Australia.
Inspired by evangelical Christianity and [abolitionism](/wiki/Abolitionism
"Abolitionism"), Wakefield's essays (1829 to 1849), condemned both slavery and
indentured and convict labour as immoral, unjust, and inefficient. Instead, he
proposed a government sponsored system in which the price of farm land was set
at a high enough level to prevent urban workers from easily purchasing it and
thus leaving the labour market. His colonisation programmes were over-
elaborate and operated on a much smaller scale than he hoped for, but his
ideas influenced law and culture, especially his vision for the colony as the
embodiment of post-Enlightenment ideals, the notion of New Zealand as a model
society, and the sense of fairness in employer-employee relations.[34][35]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/William_Allsworth_-
_The_emigrants_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/220px-William_Allsworth_-
_The_emigrants_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)](/wiki/File:William_Allsworth_-
_The_emigrants_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:William_Allsworth_-_The_emigrants_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg
"Enlarge")

Scottish Highland family migrating to New Zealand, 1844

Settlement continued under British plans, inspired by a vision of New Zealand
as a new land of opportunity; the Pākehā population grew explosively from
fewer than 1000 in 1831 to 500,000 by 1881. Some 400,000 settlers came from
Britain, of whom 300,000 stayed permanently. Most were young people and
250,000 babies were born. The passage of 120,000 was paid by the colonial
government. After 1880 immigration reduced, and growth was due chiefly to the
excess of births over deaths.[36]

In 1846, the British Parliament drafted eleborate plans for a form of self-
government for the 13,000 settlers in New Zealand. The new Governor, [George
Grey](/wiki/George_Grey "George Grey"), suspended the plans. He argued that
the Pākehā could not be trusted to pass laws that would protect the interests
of the Māori majority — already there had been Treaty violations – and
persuaded his political superiors to postpone its introduction for five
years.[37]

depression[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=9
