### Colonial self-government,
1850s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Colonial self-government, 1850s")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/First_Government_House%2C_Auckland.jpg/220px-
First_Government_House%2C_Auckland.jpg)](/wiki/File:First_Government_House,_Auckland.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:First_Government_House,_Auckland.jpg "Enlarge")

The first [Government House](/wiki/Government_House,_Auckland "Government
House, Auckland") in Auckland, as painted by [Edward
Ashworth](/wiki/Edward_Ashworth "Edward Ashworth") in 1842 or 1843. Auckland
was the second [capital of New Zealand](/wiki/Capital_of_New_Zealand "Capital
of New Zealand").

When the British settlers petititoned for self-government, the British
Parliament passed the [New Zealand Constitution Act
1852](/wiki/New_Zealand_Constitution_Act_1852 "New Zealand Constitution Act
1852"), setting up a central government with an elected [General Assembly
(Parliament)](/wiki/New_Zealand_Parliament "New Zealand Parliament") and six
provincial governments.[38] The General Assembly did not meet until 24 May
1854, 16 months after the Constitution Act had come into force.
[Provinces](/wiki/Provinces_of_New_Zealand "Provinces of New Zealand") were
reorganised in 1846 and in 1853, when they acquired their own legislatures,
and then abolished with effect in 1877.[39] The settlers soon won the right to
[responsible government](/wiki/Responsible_government "Responsible
government") (with an executive supported by a majority in the elected
assembly). But the governor, and through him the Colonial Office in London,
retained control of [native](/wiki/Indigenous_people "Indigenous people")
policy until the mid-1860s.[40]

### Farming and
mining[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Farming and mining")]

Main article: [Otago Gold Rush](/wiki/Otago_Gold_Rush "Otago Gold Rush")

The Māori tribes at first sold the land to the settlers, but the government
voided the sales in 1840. Now only the government was allowed to purchase land
from Māori, who received cash. The government bought practically all the
useful land, then resold it to the [New Zealand
Company](/wiki/New_Zealand_Company "New Zealand Company"), which promoted
immigration, or leased it for sheep runs. The Company resold the best tracts
to British settlers; its profits were used to pay the travel of the immigrants
from Britain.[41][42]

Because of the vast distances involved, the first settlers were self-
sufficient farmers. By the 1840s, however, large scale sheep stations were
exporting large quantities of wool to the textile mills of England. Most of
the early settlers were brought over by a programme operated by the New
Zealand Company and were located in the central region on either side of Cook
Strait, and at Wellington, Wanganui, New Plymouth and Nelson. These
settlements had access to some of the richest plains in the country and after
refrigerated ships appeared in 1882, they developed into closely settled
regions of small-scale farming. Outside these compact settlements were the
sheep runs. Pioneer pastoralists, often men with experience as squatters in
Australia, leased lands from the government at the annual rate of £5 plus £1
for each 1,000 sheep above the first 5,000. The leases were renewed
automatically, which gave the wealthy pastoralists a strong landed interest
and made them a powerful political force. In all between 1856 and 1876, 8.1
million acres were sold for £7.6 million, and 2.2 million acres were given
free to soldiers, sailors and settlers.[43] With an economy based on
agriculture, the landscape was transformed from forest to farmland.

Gold discoveries in Otago (1861) and Westland (1865), caused a worldwide gold
rush that more than doubled the population in a short period, from 71,000 in
1859 to 164,000 in 1863. The value of trade increased fivefold from £2 million
to £10 million. As the gold boom ended Premier [Julius
Vogel](/wiki/Julius_Vogel "Julius Vogel") borrowed money from British
investors and launched in 1870 an ambitious programme of public works and
infrastructure investment, together with a policy of assisted immigration.[44]
Successive governments expanded the program with offices across Britain that
enticed settlers and gave them and their families one-way tickets.[45]

In the 1870s, the economy lapsed into a long depression as a result of Vogel's
borrowing and the associated debt burden (especially on land). Despite a brief
boom in wheat, prices for farm products sagged. The market for land seized up.
Hard times led to urban unemployment and [sweated labour](/wiki/Sweated_labour
"Sweated labour") (exploitative labour conditions) in industry.[46] The
country lost people through emigration, mostly to Australia.

###
Women[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Women")]

See also: [Women's suffrage in New
Zealand](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_New_Zealand "Women's suffrage in New
Zealand")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Tribute_to_the_Suffragettes%2C_close_up.jpg/220px-
Tribute_to_the_Suffragettes%2C_close_up.jpg)](/wiki/File:Tribute_to_the_Suffragettes,_close_up.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Tribute_to_the_Suffragettes,_close_up.jpg "Enlarge")

_Tribute to the Suffragettes_ memorial in [Christchurch](/wiki/Christchurch
"Christchurch") adjacent to [Our City](/wiki/Our_City,_Christchurch "Our City,
Christchurch"). The figures shown from left to right are [Amey
Daldy](/wiki/Amey_Daldy "Amey Daldy"), [Kate Sheppard](/wiki/Kate_Sheppard
"Kate Sheppard"), [Ada Wells](/wiki/Ada_Wells "Ada Wells") and [Harriet
Morison](/wiki/Harriet_Morison "Harriet Morison")

Although norms of masculinity were dominant, strong minded women originated a
[feminist movement](/wiki/Feminism_in_New_Zealand "Feminism in New Zealand")
starting in the 1860s, well before women gained the right to vote in 1893.[47]
Middle class women employed the media (especially newspapers) to communicate
with each other and define their priorities. Prominent feminist writers
included Mary Taylor,[48] [Mary Colclough](/wiki/Mary_Ann_Colclough "Mary Ann
Colclough") (pseud. Polly Plum),[49] and Ellen Ellis.[50] The first signs of a
politicised collective female identity came in crusades to pass the Contagious
Diseases Prevention Act.[51][52]

Feminists by the 1880s were using the rhetoric of "white slavery" to reveal
men's sexual and social oppression of women. By demanding that men take
responsibility for the right of women to walk the streets in safety, New
Zealand feminists deployed the rhetoric of white slavery to argue for women's
sexual and social freedom.[53] Middle class women successfully mobilised to
stop prostitution, especially during the First World War.[54]

Māori women developed their own form of feminism, derived from [Māori
nationalism](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_nationalism "Māori nationalism") rather than
European sources.[55][56]

In 1893 [Elizabeth Yates](/wiki/Elizabeth_Yates_\(mayor\) "Elizabeth Yates
\(mayor\)") was elected mayor of Onehunga, making her the first woman in the
British Empire to hold the office. She was an able administrator: she cut the
debt, reorganised the fire brigade, and improved the roads and sanitation.
Many men were hostile however, and she was defeated for re-election.[57]
Hutching argues that after 1890 women were increasingly well organised through
the National Council of Women, the Women's Christian Temperance Union (WCTU),
the Women's International League, and the Housewives Union, and others. By
1910 they were campaigning for peace, and against compulsory military
training, and conscription. They demanded arbitration and the peaceful
resolution of international disputes. The women argued that womenhood (thanks
to motherhood) was the repository of superior moral values and concerns and
from their domestic experience they knew best how to resolve conflicts.[58]

###
Schools[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Schools")]

Main article: [History of education in New
Zealand](/wiki/History_of_education_in_New_Zealand "History of education in
New Zealand")

Prior to 1877 schools were operated by the provincial government, churches, or
by private subscription. Education was not a requirement and many children did
not attend any school, especially farm children whose labour was important to
the family economy. The quality of education provided varied substantially
depending on the school. The Education Act of 1877 created New Zealand's first
free national system of primary education, establishing standards that
educators should meet, and making education compulsory for children aged 5 to
15.

###
Immigration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Immigration")]

Main article: [Immigration to New Zealand](/wiki/Immigration_to_New_Zealand
"Immigration to New Zealand")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Scottish_poster_advertising_emigration_to_New_Zealand.jpg/220px-
Scottish_poster_advertising_emigration_to_New_Zealand.jpg)](/wiki/File:Scottish_poster_advertising_emigration_to_New_Zealand.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Scottish_poster_advertising_emigration_to_New_Zealand.jpg
"Enlarge")

"First Scottish Colony for New Zealand" – 1839 poster advertising emigration
from Scotland to New Zealand. Collection of [Kelvingrove Art Gallery and
Museum](/wiki/Kelvingrove_Art_Gallery_and_Museum "Kelvingrove Art Gallery and
Museum"), Glasgow, Scotland.

From 1840 there was considerable European settlement, primarily from England
and Wales, Scotland and Ireland; and to a lesser extent the United States,
India, China, and various parts of [continental
Europe](/wiki/Continental_Europe "Continental Europe"), including the province
of [Dalmatia](/wiki/Dalmatia "Dalmatia")[59] in what is now
[Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), and [Bohemia](/wiki/Bohemia "Bohemia")[60]
in what is now the Czech Republic. Already a majority of the population by
1859, the number of Pākehā settlers increased rapidly to reach over one
million by 1916.[61]

In the 1870s and 1880s, several thousand Chinese men, mostly from
[Guangdong](/wiki/Guangdong "Guangdong"), migrated to New Zealand to work on
the South Island goldfields. Although the first Chinese migrants had been
invited by the [Otago](/wiki/Otago "Otago") Provincial government they quickly
became the target of hostility from white settlers and laws were enacted
specifically to discourage them from coming to New Zealand.[62]

### Māori adaptation and
resistance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Māori adaptation and resistance")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/WilliamsNorthStar1845.jpg/220px-
WilliamsNorthStar1845.jpg)](/wiki/File:WilliamsNorthStar1845.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:WilliamsNorthStar1845.jpg "Enlarge")

[HMS _North Star_](/wiki/HMS_North_Star_\(1824\) "HMS North Star \(1824\)")
destroying Pomare's Pā during the Northern/Flagstaff War, 1845, Painting by
John Williams.[63]

Māori had welcomed Pākehā for the trading opportunities and guns they brought.
However it soon became clear that they had underestimated the number of
settlers that would arrive in their lands. _[Iwi](/wiki/Iwi "Iwi")_ (tribes)
whose land was the base of the main settlements quickly lost much of their
land and autonomy through government acts. Others prospered – until about 1860
the city of [Auckland](/wiki/Auckland "Auckland") bought most of its food from
Māori who grew and sold it themselves. Many _iwi_ owned flour mills, ships and
other items of European technology, some exported food to Australia for a
brief period during the 1850s gold rush. Although race relations were
generally peaceful in this period, there were conflicts over who had ultimate
power in particular areas – the Governor or the Māori chiefs. One such
conflict was the Northern or [Flagstaff War](/wiki/Flagstaff_War "Flagstaff
War") of the 1840s, during which [Kororareka](/wiki/Kororareka "Kororareka")
was sacked.

As the Pākehā population grew, pressure grew on Māori to sell more land. Land
is not only an economic resource, but also one basis of Māori identity and a
connection with their ancestor's bones. Land was used communally, but under
the mana of chiefs. In Māori culture there was no such idea as selling land
until the arrival of Europeans. The means of acquiring land was to defeat
another hapu or iwi in battle and seize their land. Te Rauparaha seized the
land of many lower North Island and upper South Island iwi during the musket
wars. Land was usually not given up without discussion and consultation. When
an iwi was divided over the question of selling this could lead to great
difficulties as at Waitara.

Pākehā had little understanding of all that and accused Māori of holding onto
land they did not use efficiently. Competition for land was one important
cause of the [New Zealand Wars](/wiki/New_Zealand_Wars "New Zealand Wars") of
the 1860s and 1870s, in which the [Taranaki](/wiki/Taranaki "Taranaki") and
[Waikato](/wiki/Waikato "Waikato") regions were invaded by colonial troops and
Māori of these regions had some of their land taken from them. The wars and
confiscation left bitterness that remains to this day. After the conclusion of
the Land Wars some iwi, especially in the Waikato, such as Ngati Haua sold
land freely. However, only the chiefs and their whanau benefited from this
income. The 2013 Ngati Haua treaty settlement recognised that many Ngati Haua
had not received any benefit from the large payments in the 1870s hence the
government was paying compensation.

Some iwi sided with the government and, later, fought with the government.
They were motivated partly by the thought that an alliance with the government
would benefit them, and partly by old feuds with the iwi they fought against.
One result of their co-operation strategy was the establishment of the four
[Māori electorates](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_electorates "Māori electorates") in the
House of Representatives, in 1867.

After the wars, some Māori began a strategy of [passive
resistance](/wiki/Passive_resistance "Passive resistance"), most famously at
[Parihaka](/wiki/Parihaka "Parihaka") in Taranaki. Most, such as NgaPuhi and
Arawa continued co-operating with Pākehā. For example, tourism ventures were
established by [Te Arawa](/wiki/Te_Arawa "Te Arawa") around
[Rotorua](/wiki/Rotorua "Rotorua"). Resisting and co-operating iwi both found
that Pākehā desire for land remained. In the last decades of the century, most
iwi lost substantial amounts of land through the activities of the [Native
Land Court](/wiki/Native_Land_Court "Native Land Court"). This was set up to
give Māori land European-style titles and to establish exactly who owned it.
Due to its Eurocentric rules, the high fees, its location remote from the
lands in question, and unfair practices by some Pākehā land agents, its main
effect was to allow Māori to sell their land without restraint from other
tribal members.

The combination of war, confiscations, disease,[64] assimilation and
intermarriage,[65] land loss leading to poor housing and alcohol abuse, and
general disillusionment, caused a fall in the Māori population from around
86,000 in 1769 to around 70,000 in 1840 and around 48,000 by 1874, hitting a
low point of 42,000 in 1896.[66] Subsequently, their numbers began to recover.

### South Island
predominance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: South Island predominance")]

See also: [South Island nationalism](/wiki/South_Island_nationalism "South
Island nationalism")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/NZ_Religious_denominations_by_TA_2013.svg/250px-
NZ_Religious_denominations_by_TA_2013.svg.png)](/wiki/File:NZ_Religious_denominations_by_TA_2013.svg)

[](/wiki/File:NZ_Religious_denominations_by_TA_2013.svg "Enlarge")

The settlement of English in the North Island and northern South Island and
Scottish in the Deep South is reflected in the dominance of
[Anglicanism](/wiki/Anglicanism "Anglicanism") and
[Presbyterianism](/wiki/Presbyterianism "Presbyterianism") in the respective
regions.

While the North Island was convulsed by the Land Wars, the South Island, with
its lower Māori population, was generally peaceful. In 1861 gold was
discovered at [Gabriel's Gully](/wiki/Gabriel%27s_Gully "Gabriel's Gully") in
[Central Otago](/wiki/Central_Otago "Central Otago"), sparking a [gold
rush](/wiki/Otago_Gold_Rush "Otago Gold Rush"). [Dunedin](/wiki/Dunedin
"Dunedin") became the wealthiest city in the country and many in the South
Island resented financing the North Island's wars. In 1865 Parliament defeated
a proposal to make the South Island independent by 17 to 31.[67]

The South Island contained most of the Pākehā population until around 1911
when the North Island again took the lead and has supported an ever-greater
majority of the country's total population through the 20th century and into
the 21st.[68]

Scottish immigrants dominated the South Island and evolved ways to bridge the
old homeland and the new. Many local Caledonian societies were formed. They
organised sports teams to entice the young and preserved an idealised Scottish
national myth (based on [Robert Burns](/wiki/Robert_Burns "Robert Burns")) for
the elderly. They gave Scots a path to assimilation and cultural integration
as [Scottish New Zealanders](/wiki/Scottish_New_Zealander "Scottish New
Zealander").[69]

## Liberal to
Labour[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Liberal to Labour")]

### Liberal asendancy,
1890s[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Liberal asendancy, 1890s")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/RichardSeddon1905.jpg/220px-
RichardSeddon1905.jpg)](/wiki/File:RichardSeddon1905.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:RichardSeddon1905.jpg "Enlarge")

Richard Seddon, Liberal Prime Minister from 1893 to his death in 1906

The pre-war era saw the advent of [party politics](/wiki/Party_politics "Party
politics"), with the establishment of the [Liberal
Government](/wiki/Liberal_Government_of_New_Zealand "Liberal Government of New
Zealand"). The landed gentry and aristocracy ruled Britain at this time. New
Zealand never had an aristocracy but it did have wealthy landowners who
largely controlled politics before 1891. The Liberal Party set out to change
that by a policy it called "populism." [Richard Seddon](/wiki/Richard_Seddon
"Richard Seddon") had proclaimed the goal as early as 1884: "It is the rich
and the poor; it is the wealthy and the landowners against the middle and
labouring classes. That, Sir, shows the real political position of New
Zealand."[70] The Liberal strategy was to create a large class of small land-
owning farmers who supported Liberal ideals.

To obtain land for farmers the Liberal government from 1891 to 1911 purchased
3.1 million acres of Māori land. The government also purchased 1.3 million
acres from large estate holders for subdivision and closer settlement by small
farmers. The Advances to Settlers Act of 1894 provided low-interest mortgages,
while the Agriculture Department disseminated information on the best farming
methods.[71][72]

The 1909 Native Land Act allowed the Māori to sell land to private buyers.
Māori still owned five million acres by 1920; they leased three million acres
and used one million acres for themselves. The Liberals proclaimed success in
forging an egalitarian, antimonopoly land policy. The policy built up support
for the Liberal party in rural North Island electorates. By 1903 the Liberals
were so dominant that there was no longer an organised opposition in
Parliament.[73][74]

### The state steps
in[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: The state steps in")]

The Liberal government laid the foundations of the later comprehensive welfare
state: introducing [old age pensions](/wiki/Old_age_pensions "Old age
pensions"); maximum hour regulations; pioneering minimum wage laws;[75] and
developing [a system for settling industrial
disputes](/wiki/Industrial_Conciliation_and_Arbitration_Act_1894 "Industrial
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1894"), which was accepted by both employers
and trade unions.[76] In 1893 it [extended voting rights to
women](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage_in_New_Zealand "Women's suffrage in New
Zealand"), making New Zealand the first country in the world to enact
[universal female suffrage](/wiki/Women%27s_suffrage "Women's suffrage").[77]

New Zealand gained international attention for its reforms, especially how the
state regulated labour relations.[78] The impact was especially strong on the
reform movement in the United States.[79]

Coleman argues that the Liberals in 1891 lacked a clear-cut ideology to guide
them. Instead they approached the nation's problems pragmatically, keeping in
mind the constraints imposed by democratic public opinion. To deal with the
issue of land distribution, they worked out innovative solutions to access,
tenure, and a graduated tax on unimproved values.[80]

### Economic
developments[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Economic developments")]

During the 1880s, New Zealand's economy grew from one based on wool and local
trade to the export of wool, cheese, butter and frozen beef and mutton to
Britain. The change was enabled by the invention of refrigerated steamships in
1882 and a result of the large market demands overseas. In order to increase
production, alongside a more intensive use of factor inputs a transformation
of production techniques was necessary. The required capital came mainly from
outside of New Zealand.[81] Refrigerated shipping remained the basis of [New
Zealand's economy](/wiki/Economy_of_New_Zealand "Economy of New Zealand")
until the 1970s. New Zealand's highly productive agriculture gave it probably
the world's highest standard of living, with fewer at the rich and poor ends
of the scale.[82]

During this era (c. 1880 – c. 1914) the banking system was weak and there was
little foreign investment, so businessmen had to build up their own capital.
Historians have debated whether the "long depression" of the late 19th century
stifled investment, but the New Zealanders found a way around adverse
conditions. Hunter has studied the experiences of 133 entrepreneurs who
started commercial enterprises between 1880 and 1910. The successful strategy
was to deploy capital economising techniques, and reinvesting profits rather
than borrowing. The result was slow but stable growth that avoided bubbles and
led to long-lived family owned firms.[83][84]

### Dominion
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Dominion status")]

Main articles: [Dominion of New Zealand](/wiki/Dominion_of_New_Zealand
"Dominion of New Zealand") and [Independence of New
Zealand](/wiki/Independence_of_New_Zealand "Independence of New Zealand")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Australian_ogre_1900.jpg/220px-
Australian_ogre_1900.jpg)](/wiki/File:Australian_ogre_1900.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Australian_ogre_1900.jpg "Enlarge")

[Zealandia](/wiki/Zealandia_\(personification\) "Zealandia
\(personification\)") rejecting [Australian
Constitution](/wiki/Australian_Constitution "Australian Constitution") in 1900

New Zealand initially expressed interest in joining the proposed
[Federation](/wiki/Federation_of_Australia "Federation of Australia") of the
Australian colonies, attending the 1891 National Australia Convention in
Sydney. Interest in the proposed Australian Federation faded and New Zealand
decided against joining the [Commonwealth of
Australia](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Australia "Commonwealth of Australia") in
1901.[85] New Zealand instead changed from being a colony to a separate
"Dominion" in 1907, equal in status to Australia and Canada. Dominion status
was a public mark of the self-governance that had evolved over half a century
through responsible government.[86] Just under one million people lived in New
Zealand in 1907 and cities such as Auckland and Wellington were growing
rapidly.[87]

### Temperance and
prohibition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Temperance and prohibition")]

Further information: [Temperance movement in New
Zealand](/wiki/Temperance_movement_in_New_Zealand "Temperance movement in New
Zealand")

In New Zealand, [prohibition](/wiki/Prohibition "Prohibition") was a
moralistic reform movement begun in the mid-1880s by the Protestant
evangelical and Nonconformist churches and the [Woman's Christian Temperance
Union](/wiki/Woman%27s_Christian_Temperance_Union "Woman's Christian
Temperance Union") and after 1890 by the [Prohibition
League](/w/index.php?title=Prohibition_League&action=edit&redlink=1
"Prohibition League \(page does not exist\)").[88] It never achieved its goal
of national prohibition. It was a middle-class movement which accepted the
existing economic and social order; the effort to legislate morality assumed
that individual redemption was all that was needed to carry the colony forward
from a pioneering society to a more mature one. However, both the Church of
England and the largely Irish Catholic Church rejected prohibition as an
intrusion of government into the church's domain, while the growing labour
movement saw capitalism rather than alcohol as the enemy. Reformers hoped that
the women's vote, in which New Zealand was a pioneer, would swing the balance,
but the women were not as well organised as in other countries. Prohibition
had a majority in a national referendum in 1911, but needed a 60% majority to
pass.[89] The movement kept trying in the 1920s, losing three more referenda
by close votes; it managed to keep in place a 6 pm closing hour for pubs and
Sunday closing (leading to the so-called [six o'clock
swill](/wiki/Six_o%27clock_swill "Six o'clock swill")[90]). The Depression and
war years effectively ended the movement.[88]

### First World
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: First World War")]

Main article: [Military history of New Zealand during World War
I](/wiki/Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_I "Military history
of New Zealand during World War I")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/A_World_War_1_Story%2C_Part_6._Hutt_Valley%2C_Wellington%2C_New_Zealand%2C_14_April_1916_%28437353411%29.jpg/220px-
A_World_War_1_Story%2C_Part_6._Hutt_Valley%2C_Wellington%2C_New_Zealand%2C_14_April_1916_%28437353411%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_World_War_1_Story,_Part_6._Hutt_Valley,_Wellington,_New_Zealand,_14_April_1916_\(437353411\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_World_War_1_Story,_Part_6._Hutt_Valley,_Wellington,_New_Zealand,_14_April_1916_\(437353411\).jpg
"Enlarge")

New Zealand Division in 1916

The country remained an enthusiastic member of the [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"), and 110,000 men fought in
[World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I") (see [New Zealand Expeditionary
Force](/wiki/New_Zealand_Expeditionary_Force "New Zealand Expeditionary
Force")). 16,688 died. Conscription had been in force since 1909, and while it
was opposed in peacetime there was less opposition during the war. The labour
movement was pacifistic, opposed the war, and alleged that the rich were
benefitting at the expense of the workers. It formed the [New Zealand Labour
Party](/wiki/New_Zealand_Labour_Party "New Zealand Labour Party") in 1916.
Māori tribes that had been close to the government sent their young men to
volunteer. Unlike in Britain, relatively few women became involved. Women did
serve as nurses; 640 joined the services and 500 went overseas.[91][92]

New Zealand forces captured [Western Samoa](/wiki/Western_Samoa "Western
Samoa") from Germany in the early stages of the war, and New Zealand
administered the country until Samoan Independence in 1962.[93] However
Samoans greatly resented the imperialism, and blamed inflation and the
catastrophic 1918 flu epidemic on New Zealand rule.[94]

The heroism of the soldiers in the failed [Gallipoli
Campaign](/wiki/Gallipoli_Campaign "Gallipoli Campaign") made their sacrifices
iconic in New Zealand memory, and is often credited with securing the
psychological independence of the nation.[95][96]

### Imperial
loyalties[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Imperial loyalties")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/ImperialConference.jpg/220px-
ImperialConference.jpg)](/wiki/File:ImperialConference.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ImperialConference.jpg "Enlarge")

[George V](/wiki/George_V "George V") with his prime ministers at the [1926
Imperial Conference](/wiki/1926_Imperial_Conference "1926 Imperial
Conference"). Standing (left to right): [Monroe](/wiki/Walter_Stanley_Monroe
"Walter Stanley Monroe") ([Newfoundland](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Newfoundland
"Prime Minister of Newfoundland")), [Coates](/wiki/Gordon_Coates "Gordon
Coates") ([New Zealand](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_New_Zealand "Prime Minister of
New Zealand")), [Bruce](/wiki/Stanley_Bruce "Stanley Bruce")
([Australia](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Australia "Prime Minister of
Australia")), [Hertzog](/wiki/J._B._M._Hertzog "J. B. M. Hertzog") ([Union of
South Africa](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_South_Africa "Prime Minister of South
Africa")), [Cosgrave](/wiki/W._T._Cosgrave "W. T. Cosgrave") ([Irish Free
State](/wiki/President_of_the_Executive_Council_of_the_Irish_Free_State
"President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State")). Seated:
[Baldwin](/wiki/Stanley_Baldwin "Stanley Baldwin")
([UK](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the United
Kingdom")), King George V, [King](/wiki/William_Lyon_Mackenzie_King "William
Lyon Mackenzie King") ([Canada](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Canada "Prime Minister
of Canada")).

After the war New Zealand signed the Treaty of Versailles (1919), joined the
[League of Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations") and pursued
an independent foreign policy, while its defence was still controlled by
Britain. New Zealand depended on Britain's Royal Navy for its military
security during the 1920s and 1930s. Officials in Wellington trusted
Conservative Party governments in London, but not Labour. When the British
Labour Party took power in 1924 and 1929, the New Zealand government felt
threatened by Labour's foreign policy because of its reliance upon the League
of Nations. The League was distrusted and Wellington did not expect to see the
coming of a peaceful world order under League auspices. What had been the
Empire's most loyal dominion became a dissenter as it opposed efforts the
first and second British Labour governments to trust the League's framework of
arbitration and collective security agreements.[97]

The governments of the Reform and United parties between 1912 and 1935
followed a "realistic" foreign policy. They made national security a high
priority, were sceptical of international institutions, and showed no interest
on the questions of self-determination, democracy, and human rights. However
the opposition Labour Party was more idealistic and proposed a liberal
internationalist outlook on international affairs.[98]

The Labour Party emerged as a force in 1919 with a
[socialist](/wiki/Socialism_in_New_Zealand "Socialism in New Zealand")
platform. It won about 25% of the vote. However its appeals to working class
solidarity were not effective because a large fraction of the working class
voted for conservative candidates of the Liberal and Reform parties. (They
merged in 1936 to form the [New Zealand National
Party](/wiki/New_Zealand_National_Party "New Zealand National Party").) As a
consequence the Labour party was able to jettison its support for socialism in
1927 (a policy made official in 1951), as it expanded its reach into middle
class constituencies. The result was a jump in strength to 35% in 1931, 47% in
1935, and peaking at 56% in 1938.[99] From 1935 the [First Labour
Government](/wiki/First_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand "First Labour
Government of New Zealand") showed a limited degree of idealism in foreign
policy, for example opposing the appeasement of Germany and Japan.[98]

### Great
Depression[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Great Depression")]

Like most other countries, New Zealand was hard hit by the [Great
Depression](/wiki/Great_Depression "Great Depression") of the 1930s, which
affected the country via its international trade, with farming export drops
then going on to affect the money supply and in turn consumption, investment
and imports. The country was most affected around 1930–1932, when average farm
incomes for a short time dipped below zero, and the unemployment rates peaked.
Though actual unemployment numbers were not officially counted, the country
was affected especially strongly in the North Island.[100]

Unlike later years, there were no public benefit ('dole') payments – the
unemployed were given 'relief work', much of which was however not very
productive, partly because the size of the problem was unprecedented. Women
also increasingly registered as unemployed, while Māori received government
help through other channels such as the land development schemes organised by
[Āpirana Ngata](/wiki/%C4%80pirana_Ngata "Āpirana Ngata"). In 1933, 8.5% of
the unemployed were organised in work camps, while the rest received work
close to their homes. Typical occupations in relief work were road work
(undertaken by 45% of all part-time and 19% of all full-time relief workers in
1934, with park improvement works (17%) and farm work (31%) being the other
two most common types of work for part-time and full-time relief workers
respectively).[100]

### Building the welfare
state[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Building the welfare state")]

Further information: [Welfare in New Zealand](/wiki/Welfare_in_New_Zealand
"Welfare in New Zealand")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Labour_Cabinet%2C_1935.jpg/220px-
Labour_Cabinet%2C_1935.jpg)](/wiki/File:Labour_Cabinet,_1935.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Labour_Cabinet,_1935.jpg "Enlarge")

The [1935 Labour Cabinet](/wiki/First_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand "First
Labour Government of New Zealand"). Michael Joseph Savage is seated in the
front row, centre.

Attempts by the [United-Reform Coalition](/wiki/United-Reform_Coalition
"United-Reform Coalition") to deal with the situation with spending cuts and
relief work were ineffective and unpopular. In 1935, the [First Labour
Government](/wiki/First_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand "First Labour
Government of New Zealand") was elected, and the post-depression decade showed
that average Labour support in New Zealand had roughly doubled comparable to
pre-depression times. By 1935 economic conditions had improved somewhat, and
the new government had more positive financial conditions.[100] Prime Minister
[Michael Joseph Savage](/wiki/Michael_Joseph_Savage "Michael Joseph Savage")
proclaimed that: "Social Justice must be the guiding principle and economic
organization must adapt itself to social needs."[101]

The new government quickly set about implementing a number of significant
reforms, including a reorganisation of the social welfare system and the
creation of the [state housing](/wiki/State_housing "State housing") scheme.
Labour also gained Māori votes by working closely with the
[Rātana](/wiki/R%C4%81tana "Rātana") movement. Savage was idolised by the
working classes, and his portrait hung on the walls of many houses around the
country. The newly created [welfare state](/wiki/Welfare_state "Welfare
state") promised government support to individuals "from the cradle to the
grave", according to the Labour slogan. It included free health care and
education, and state assistance for the elderly, infirm, and unemployed. The
opposition attacked the Labour Party's more left-wing policies, and accused it
of undermining free enterprise and hard work. The Reform Party and the United
Party merged to become the [National Party](/wiki/New_Zealand_National_Party
"New Zealand National Party"), and would be Labour's main rival in future
years. However the welfare state system was retained and expanded by
successive National and Labour governments until the 1980s.[102]

### Second World
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Second World War")]

Main article: [Military history of New Zealand during World War
II](/wiki/Military_history_of_New_Zealand_during_World_War_II "Military
history of New Zealand during World War II")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/Dominion_and_Empire_Forces_in_the_United_Kingdom%2C_1939-1945_H1830.jpg/220px-
Dominion_and_Empire_Forces_in_the_United_Kingdom%2C_1939-1945_H1830.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dominion_and_Empire_Forces_in_the_United_Kingdom,_1939-1945_H1830.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dominion_and_Empire_Forces_in_the_United_Kingdom,_1939-1945_H1830.jpg
"Enlarge")

Men of the [Māori Battalion](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_Battalion "Māori Battalion"),
New Zealand Expeditionary Force, after disembarking at Gourock in Scotland in
June 1940

When [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") broke out in 1939, New
Zealanders saw their proper role as defending their proud place in the British
Empire. It contributed some 120,000 troops. They mostly fought in North
Africa, Greece/Crete, and Italy, relying on the [Royal Navy](/wiki/Royal_Navy
"Royal Navy") and later the United States to protect New Zealand from the
Japanese forces. Japan had no interest in New Zealand in the first place; it
had already over-reached when it invaded New Guinea in 1942. (There were a few
highly publicised but ineffective Japanese scouting incursions.) The [3rd New
Zealand Division](/wiki/3rd_New_Zealand_Division "3rd New Zealand Division")
fought in the Solomons in 1943–44, but New Zealand's limited manpower meant 2
Divisions could not be maintained, and it was disbanded and its men returned
to civilian life or used to reinforce the 2nd Division in Italy. The armed
forces peaked at 157,000 in September 1942; 135,000 served abroad, and 10,100
died.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/New_Zealand_-
_Her_Natural_and_Industrial_Resources_Art.IWMPST16816.jpg/220px-New_Zealand_-
_Her_Natural_and_Industrial_Resources_Art.IWMPST16816.jpg)](/wiki/File:New_Zealand_-
_Her_Natural_and_Industrial_Resources_Art.IWMPST16816.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:New_Zealand_-
_Her_Natural_and_Industrial_Resources_Art.IWMPST16816.jpg "Enlarge")

A 1943 poster produced during the war. The poster reads: "When war broke out
... industries were unprepared for munitions production. To-day New Zealand is
not only manufacturing many kinds of munitions for her own defence but is
making a valuable contribution to the defence of the other areas in the
Pacific..."

New Zealand, with a population of 1.7 million, including 99,000 Māori, was
highly mobilised during the war.[103] The Labour party was in power and
promoted unionisation and the welfare state. Agriculture expanded, sending
record supplies of meat, butter and wool to Britain. When American forces
arrived, they were fed as well.

The nation spent £574 million on the war, of which 43% came from taxes, 41%
from loans and 16% from American [Lend Lease](/wiki/Lend_Lease "Lend Lease").
It was an era of prosperity as the national income soared from £158 million in
1937 to £292 million in 1944. Rationing and price controls kept inflation to
only 14% during 1939–45.[104]

Over £50 million was spent on defence works and military accommodation and
hospitals, including 292 mi (470 km) of roads.[105]

Montgomerie shows that the war dramatically increased the roles of women,
especially married women, in the labour force. Most of them took traditional
female jobs. Some replaced men but the changes here were temporary and
reversed in 1945. After the war, women left traditional male occupations and
many women gave up paid employment to return home. There was no radical change
in gender roles but the war intensified occupational trends under way since
the 1920s.[106][107]

## The later 20th
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: The later 20th century")]

### National in
power[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: National in power")]

Labour remained in power after the Second World War and in 1945, Labour Prime
Minister [Peter Fraser](/wiki/Peter_Fraser_\(New_Zealand_politician\) "Peter
Fraser \(New Zealand politician\)") played an important role in the
establishment of the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations"),
of which New Zealand was [a founding
member](/wiki/New_Zealand_and_the_United_Nations "New Zealand and the United
Nations").[108] However, domestically Labour had lost the reforming zeal of
the 1930s and its electoral support ebbed after the war. After Labour lost
power in 1949, the conservative National Party began an almost continuous
thirty-year stint in government, interrupted by single-term Labour governments
in 1957 to 60 and 1972 to 75. National Prime Minister [Sidney
Holland](/wiki/Sidney_Holland "Sidney Holland") called a snap election as a
result of the [1951 waterfront
dispute](/wiki/1951_New_Zealand_waterfront_dispute "1951 New Zealand
waterfront dispute"), an incident that reinforced National's dominance and
severely weakened the union movement.[109]

Cooperation with the United States set a direction of policy which resulted in
the [ANZUS](/wiki/ANZUS "ANZUS") Treaty between New Zealand, America and
Australia in 1951, as well as participation in the [Korean
War](/wiki/New_Zealand_in_the_Korean_War "New Zealand in the Korean
War").[110]

### The British
connection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: The British connection")]

Fedorowich and Bridge argue that the demands of the Second World War produced
long-term consequences for New Zealand's relationship with the government in
London. The key component was the office of the [high
commissioner](/wiki/High_commissioner "High commissioner"). By 1950 it was the
main line of communications between the British and New Zealand
governments.[111]

1950s New Zealand culture was deeply British and conservative, with the
concept of "fairness" holding a central role.[112] New immigrants, still
mainly British, flooded in while New Zealand remained prosperous by exporting
farm products to Britain. In 1953 New Zealanders took pride that a countryman,
[Edmund Hillary](/wiki/Edmund_Hillary "Edmund Hillary"), gave [Queen Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II") a [coronation
gift](/wiki/Coronation_of_Elizabeth_II "Coronation of Elizabeth II") by
reaching the summit of Mount Everest.[113]

From the 1890s, the economy had been based almost entirely on the export of
frozen meat and dairy products to Britain, and in 1961, the share of New
Zealand exports going to the United Kingdom was still at slightly over 51%,
with approximately 15% more going to other European countries.[114] The 1960s
was a decade of rising prosperity for most New Zealanders, but from 1965 there
were also protests – in support of women's rights and the nascent ecological
movement, and against the [Vietnam War](/wiki/New_Zealand_in_the_Vietnam_War
"New Zealand in the Vietnam War").[115] Irrespective of political
developments, many New Zealanders still perceived themselves as a distinctive
outlying branch of the United Kingdom until at least the 1970s. In 1973
Britain joined the European Community and abrogated its preferential trade
agreements with New Zealand (see below), forcing New Zealand to not only find
new markets, but also re-examine its national identity and place in the
world.[116]

### Māori
urbanisation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Māori urbanisation")]

Māori always had a high birth rate; that was neutralised by a high death rate
until modern public health measures became effective in the 20th century when
tuberculosis deaths and infant mortality declined sharply. Life expectancy
grew from 49 years in 1926 to 60 years in 1961 and the total numbers grew
rapidly.[117] Many Māori served in the Second World War and learned how to
cope in the modern urban world; others moved from their rural homes to the
cities to take up jobs vacated by Pākehā servicemen.[118] The shift to the
cities was also caused by their strong birth rates in the early 20th century,
with the existing rural farms in Māori ownership having increasing difficulty
in providing enough jobs.[118] Māori culture had meanwhile undergone a
renaissance thanks in part to politician [Āpirana
Ngata](/wiki/%C4%80pirana_Ngata "Āpirana Ngata").[119] By the 1980s 80% of the
Māori population was urban, in contrast to only 20% before the Second World
War. The migration led to better pay, higher standards of living and longer
schooling, but also exposed problems of racism and discrimination. By the late
1960s a [protest movement](/wiki/M%C4%81ori_protest_movement "Māori protest
movement") had emerged to combat racism, promote Māori culture and seek
fulfilment of the Treaty of Waitangi.[120]

Urbanisation proceeded rapidly across the land. In the late 1940s, town
planners noted that the country was "possibly the third most urbanised country
in the world",[121] with two-thirds of the population living in cities or
towns. There was also increasing concern that this trend was badly managed,
with it being noted that there was an "ill-defined urban pattern that appears
to have few of the truly desirable urban qualities and yet manifests no
compensating rural characteristics."[121]

### The Muldoon years,
1975–1984[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: The Muldoon years, 1975–1984")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/New_Zealand_Cabinet%2C_1981.jpg/250px-
New_Zealand_Cabinet%2C_1981.jpg)](/wiki/File:New_Zealand_Cabinet,_1981.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:New_Zealand_Cabinet,_1981.jpg "Enlarge")

[Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") and Muldoon's Cabinet, taken
during the Queen's 1981 tour of New Zealand

The country's economy suffered in the aftermath of the 1973 global energy
crisis, the loss of New Zealand's biggest export market upon Britain's entry
to the [European Economic Community](/wiki/European_Economic_Community
"European Economic Community"), and rampant inflation.[116] [Robert
Muldoon](/wiki/Robert_Muldoon "Robert Muldoon"), Prime Minister from 1975 to
1984, and his [Third National
Government](/wiki/Third_National_Government_of_New_Zealand "Third National
Government of New Zealand") responded to the crises of the 1970s by attempting
to preserve the New Zealand of the 1950s. He attempted to maintain New
Zealand's "cradle to the grave" welfare state, which dated to 1935. His
government sought to give retirees 80% of the current wage, which would
require large-scale borrowing; critics said it would bankrupt the treasury.
Muldoon's response to the crisis also involved imposing a total freeze on
wages, prices, interest rates and dividends across the national economy.[122]

Muldoon's conservatism and antagonistic style exacerbated an atmosphere of
conflict in New Zealand, most violently expressed during the [1981 Springbok
Tour](/wiki/1981_Springbok_Tour "1981 Springbok Tour").[123] In the 1984
elections Labour promised to calm down the increasing tensions, while making
no specific promises; it scored a landslide victory.[122]

However, Muldoon's government was not entirely backward looking. Some
innovations did take place, for example the [Closer Economic
Relations](/wiki/Closer_Economic_Relations "Closer Economic Relations") (CER)
free-trade programme with Australia to liberalise trade, starting in 1982. The
aim of total free trade between the two countries was achieved in 1990, five
years ahead of schedule.[124]

### The radical 1980s
reforms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: The radical 1980s reforms")]

In 1984, the [Fourth Labour
Government](/wiki/Fourth_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand "Fourth Labour
Government of New Zealand"), led by [David Lange](/wiki/David_Lange "David
Lange"), was elected amid a [constitutional and economic
crisis](/wiki/1984_New_Zealand_constitutional_crisis "1984 New Zealand
constitutional crisis"). The crisis led the incoming government to review New
Zealand's constitutional structures, which resulted in the [Constitution Act
1986](/wiki/Constitution_Act_1986 "Constitution Act 1986").[125] In power from
1984 to 1990, the Labour government launched a major policy of restructuring
the economy, radically reducing the role of government.[126] A political
scientist reports:

> "Between 1984 and 1993, New Zealand underwent radical economic reform,
> moving from what had probably been the most protected, regulated and state-
> dominated system of any capitalist democracy to an extreme position at the
> open, competitive, free-market end of the spectrum."[127]

The economic reforms were led by finance minister [Roger
Douglas](/wiki/Roger_Douglas "Roger Douglas") (1984–1988). Dubbed
[Rogernomics](/wiki/Rogernomics "Rogernomics"), it was a rapid programme of
deregulation and public-asset sales. Subsidies were phased out to farmers and
consumers. High finance was partly deregulated. Restrictions on foreign
exchange were relaxed and the dollar was allowed to float and seek its natural
level on the world market. The tax on high incomes was cut in half from 65% to
33%. The shares exchange entered a bubble, [which then
burst](/wiki/Black_Monday_\(1987\) "Black Monday \(1987\)"). Shares had a
total value of $50 billion in 1987 and only $15 billion in 1991; at one point
the crash was "the worst in world."[128] Overall the economic growth fell from
2% a year to 1%.[129] Douglas's reforms resembled the contemporaneous policies
of [Margaret Thatcher](/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher "Margaret Thatcher") in Britain
and [Ronald Reagan](/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan") in the United
States.[130]

Strong criticism of Rogernomics came from [the left](/wiki/Left-wing_politics
"Left-wing politics"), especially from Labour's traditional trade union
support-base; Lange broke with Douglas's policies in 1987; both men were
forced out and Labour was in confusion.[131]

In keeping with the mood of the 1980s[132] the government sponsored liberal
policies and initiatives in a number of social areas; this included
[Homosexual Law Reform](/wiki/Homosexual_Law_Reform_Act_1986 "Homosexual Law
Reform Act 1986"),[133] the introduction of '[no-fault divorce](/wiki/No-
fault_divorce "No-fault divorce")', reduction in the [gender pay
gap](/wiki/Gender_pay_gap_in_New_Zealand "Gender pay gap in New Zealand")[132]
and the drafting of a [Bill of
Rights](/wiki/New_Zealand_Bill_of_Rights_Act_1990 "New Zealand Bill of Rights
Act 1990").[134] Immigration policy was liberalised, allowing an influx of
immigrants from Asia; previously most immigrants to New Zealand had been
European and especially British.[132]

The Fourth Labour Government also revolutionised New Zealand's foreign policy,
making the country a [nuclear-free zone](/wiki/New_Zealand_nuclear-free_zone
"New Zealand nuclear-free zone") and effectively leaving the ANZUS
alliance.[135] The French intelligence service's [sinking of the _Rainbow
Warror_](/wiki/Sinking_of_the_Rainbow_Warrior "Sinking of the Rainbow
Warrior"), and the diplomatic ramifications following the incident, did much
to promote the anti-nuclear stance as an important symbol of New Zealand's
[national identity](/wiki/National_identity "National identity").[136][137]

### Continuing reform under
National[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: Continuing reform under National")]

Voters unhappy with the rapid speed and far-reaching extent of reforms elected
a [National government](/wiki/Fourth_National_Government_of_New_Zealand
"Fourth National Government of New Zealand") in 1990, led by [Jim
Bolger](/wiki/Jim_Bolger "Jim Bolger"). However the new government continued
the economic reforms of the previous Labour government, in what was known as
[Ruthanasia](/wiki/Ruthanasia "Ruthanasia").[138] Unhappy with what seemed to
be a pattern of governments failing to reflect the mood of the electorate, New
Zealanders in 1992 and 1993 voted to [change the electoral
system](/wiki/Electoral_reform_in_New_Zealand "Electoral reform in New
Zealand") to [mixed-member proportional](/wiki/Mixed-member_proportional
"Mixed-member proportional") (MMP), a form of [proportional
representation](/wiki/Proportional_representation "Proportional
representation").[139] New Zealand's [first MMP
election](/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_1996 "New Zealand general
election, 1996") was held in 1996. Following the election National was
returned to power in coalition with the [New Zealand
First](/wiki/New_Zealand_First "New Zealand First") Party.[140]

With the end of the Cold War in 1991, the nation's foreign policy turned
increasingly to issues of its nuclear-free status and other military issues;
its adjustment to neoliberalism in international trade relations; and its
involvement in humanitarian, environmental, and other matters of international
diplomacy.[141][142]

## 21st
century[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: 21st century")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Helen_Clark_and_John_Key-3%2C_UNDP.jpg/220px-
Helen_Clark_and_John_Key-3%2C_UNDP.jpg)](/wiki/File:Helen_Clark_and_John_Key-3,_UNDP.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Helen_Clark_and_John_Key-3,_UNDP.jpg "Enlarge")

Prime Ministers [John Key](/wiki/John_Key "John Key") and [Helen
Clark](/wiki/Helen_Clark "Helen Clark")

The [Fifth Labour Government](/wiki/Fifth_Labour_Government_of_New_Zealand
"Fifth Labour Government of New Zealand") led by [Helen
Clark](/wiki/Helen_Clark "Helen Clark") was elected in
[1999](/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_1999 "New Zealand general election,
1999").[143] In power for nine years, it maintained most of the previous
governments' economic reforms – restricting government intervention in the
economy much more so than previous governments – while putting more of an
emphasis on social policy and outcomes. For example, employment law was
modified to give more protection to workers,[144] and the [student loan
system](/wiki/Student_loans_in_New_Zealand "Student loans in New Zealand") was
changed to eliminate interest payments for New Zealand resident students and
graduates.[145]

New Zealand retains strong but informal links to Britain, with many young New
Zealanders travelling to Britain for their "OE" ([overseas
experience](/wiki/Overseas_experience "Overseas experience"))[146] due to
favourable working visa arrangements with Britain. Despite New Zealand's
immigration liberalisation in the 1980s, Britons are still the largest group
of migrants to New Zealand, due in part to recent immigration law changes
which privilege fluent speakers of English. One constitutional link to Britain
remains – New Zealand's head of State, the [Queen in Right of New
Zealand](/wiki/Monarchy_in_New_Zealand "Monarchy in New Zealand"), is a
British resident. However, British imperial honours were discontinued in 1996,
the Governor-General has taken a more active role in representing New Zealand
overseas, and appeals from the [Court of
Appeal](/wiki/New_Zealand_Court_of_Appeal "New Zealand Court of Appeal") to
the [Judicial Committee of the Privy
Council](/wiki/Judicial_Committee_of_the_Privy_Council "Judicial Committee of
the Privy Council") were replaced by a local [Supreme Court of New
Zealand](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_New_Zealand "Supreme Court of New Zealand") in
2003. There is public debate about whether New Zealand should [became a
republic](/wiki/Republicanism_in_New_Zealand "Republicanism in New Zealand"),
and public sentiment is divided on the issue.[147]

Foreign policy has been essentially independent since the mid-1980s. Under
Prime Minister Clark, foreign policy reflected the priorities of liberal
internationalism. She stressed the promotion of democracy and human rights;
the strengthening of the role of the United Nations; the advancement of anti-
militarism and disarmament; and the encouragement of free trade.[148] She sent
troops to the [War in
Afghanistan](/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_\(2001%E2%80%93present\) "War in
Afghanistan \(2001–present\)"), but did not contribute combat troops to the
[Iraq War](/wiki/Iraq_War "Iraq War") although some medical and engineering
units were sent.[149]

[John Key](/wiki/John_Key "John Key") led the National Party to victory in the
[November 2008](/wiki/New_Zealand_general_election,_2008 "New Zealand general
election, 2008").[150] Key became Prime Minister of the [Fifth National
Government](/wiki/Fifth_National_Government_of_New_Zealand "Fifth National
Government of New Zealand") which entered government at the beginning of the
[late-2000s recession](/wiki/Great_Recession "Great Recession"). In February
2011, a [major earthquake in Christchurch](/wiki/2011_Christchurch_earthquake
"2011 Christchurch earthquake"), the nation's second largest city,
significantly impacted the national economy and the government formed the
[Canterbury Earthquake Recovery
Authority](/wiki/Canterbury_Earthquake_Recovery_Authority "Canterbury
Earthquake Recovery Authority") in response.[151] In foreign policy, Key
announced the withdrawal of [New Zealand Defence
Force](/wiki/New_Zealand_Defence_Force "New Zealand Defence Force") personnel
[from their deployment](/wiki/International_Security_Assistance_Force#Non-
NATO_and_non-EAPC_nations "International Security Assistance Force") in the
war in Afghanistan, signed the [Wellington Declaration](/wiki/New_Zealand-
United_States_relations#Wellington_Declaration "New Zealand-United States
relations") with the United States[152] and has pushed for more nations to
join the [Trans-Pacific Strategic Economic Partnership](/wiki/Trans-
Pacific_Strategic_Economic_Partnership "Trans-Pacific Strategic Economic
Partnership").[153]

[Tourism](/wiki/Tourism_in_New_Zealand "Tourism in New Zealand") and
[agriculture](/wiki/Agriculture_in_New_Zealand "Agriculture in New Zealand")
are now the major industries that contribute to [New Zealand's
economy](/wiki/Economy_of_New_Zealand "Economy of New Zealand"). The
traditional agricultural products of meat, dairy and wool has been
supplemented by other products such as fruit, wine and timber as the economy
has diversified.[154]

## Further
reading[[edit](/w/index.php?title=History_of_New_Zealand&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: Further reading")]

Main article: [Bibliography of New Zealand
history](/wiki/Bibliography_of_New_Zealand_history "Bibliography of New
Zealand history")

  * [Michael King](/wiki/Michael_King "Michael King") (2003) _The Penguin History of New Zealand_. Immensely popular, this well-written and comprehensive single volume history is probably the best place to start for those new to New Zealand history.
  * Smith, Philippa Mein. _A Concise History of New Zealand_ (Cambridge Concise Histories) (2nd ed. 2012) 368pp; a survey by a leading scholar. [excerpt and text search](https://www.amazon.com/dp/1107402174/)
  * [James Belich](/wiki/James_Belich_\(historian\) "James Belich \(historian\)"), _Making Peoples: A History of the New Zealanders from the Polynesian settlement to the end of the nineteenth century_ (1996) and _Paradise Reforged: A History of the New Zealanders from 1880 to the Year 2000_ (2001). Although Belich’s history of New Zealand appears in two large volumes, it is not heavy going as it is full of anecdote and humour. The two books are the most academically respected histories in decades; they are very comprehensive and include several new and important theories. They are required reading for anyone making a serious study of New Zealand history.
  * [Ranginui Walker](/wiki/Ranginui_Walker "Ranginui Walker") (2004), _Ka Whawhai Tonu Matou: Struggle Without End_. The only general history written from a Māori perspective; fair, informative and interesting.
  * [Keith Sinclair](/wiki/Keith_Sinclair "Keith Sinclair"), ed., (1996) _The Oxford Illustrated History of New Zealand_. Shorter than most recent general histories and with lots of good illustrations.
  * [Keith Sinclair](/wiki/Keith_Sinclair "Keith Sinclair"), _A History of New Zealand_. First published in 1959, this is a classic of New Zealand history. Its updates consist mostly of what has happened since the previous edition, so it is seriously dated. [in Questia](https://www.questia.com/read/433660/a-history-of-new-zealand)
  * Giselle Byrnes, ed. (2009). _The New Oxford History of New Zealand_. Oxford University Press.
